body:
## PR Summary

GitHub requires TLS version 1.2 or greater, whereas Windows PowerShell ships with an older version of TLS. This sets the TLS version to use 1.2.

Resolves https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/6233

<!--

For Windows PowerShell 5.1 issues, suggestions, or feature requests please use the following link instead:
- Windows PowerShell [UserVoice](https://windowsserver.uservoice.com/forums/301869-powershell)

If it is a bug report:
- make sure you are able to repro it on the latest released version. 
You can install the latest version from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- Fill out the following repro template:

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words. 
-->
Description
------------------
Running Start-DevPowerShell or running the executable "pwsh.exe" results in new PowerShell window, but once you enter any table command, the window crashes. 

Noticed that this error occurs with fixes for pull request #5568 
Works with earlier versions however.

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/src/System.Management.Automation/FormatAndOutput/common/TableWriter.cs#L501

Assert Statement Fails

Steps to reproduce 
------------------
Run the v6.0.1 executable "pwsh.exe" from the 5.1 launcher or type Start-DevPowerShell
```powershell
Start-DevPowerShell
```
Then type in any table view command such as: 
```powershell
ls
```
Expected behavior
-----------------
Should run PowerShell v6.0.1 in a new window without crashes 

Actual behavior
---------------
Initially opens PowerShell v6.0.1, but when you type in any table view command, the window crashes. 

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->
When checking the version table in the original PowerShell Window:
```powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      5.1.15063.909
PSEdition                      Desktop
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   10.0.15063.909
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```
After running the pwsh in one instance within the same window:
```powershell
> pwsh
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.15063
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

- Fill out the following repro template:

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->

Description
------------------
This issue is caused by a mismatch in TLS certification. Windows Powershell ships with version 1 of TLS, while Github requires version 1.2.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

When building PowerShell, run the Start-PSBootstrap script
```
PS C:> Start-PSBootstrap
Installing PowerShell build dependencies
dotnet is already installed.  Skipping installation.
pwsh.exe not found. Install latest PowerShell Core release and add it to Path
VERBOSE: Destination: C:\Users\joelj\AppData\Local\Microsoft\powershell
VERBOSE: About to download package from
'https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/download/v6.0.1/PowerShell-6.0.1-win-x64.zip'
Invoke-WebRequest : The request was aborted: Could not create SSL/TLS secure channel.
At D:\HackIllinois2018\Powershell\PowerShell\tools\install-powershell.ps1:139 char:9
+         Invoke-WebRequest -Uri $downloadURL -OutFile $packagePath
+         ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: (System.Net.HttpWebRequest:HttpWebRequest) [Invoke-WebRequest], WebExc
   eption
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : WebCmdletWebResponseException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.InvokeWebRequestCommand
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

Script is able to establish a secure channel that matches default Windows certificates

Actual behavior
---------------


Error is returned: The request was aborted: could not create SSL/TLS secure channel.


Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----

BuildVersion                   10.0.16299.248
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```

body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------

1. Type on an NTFS/ReFS file system:
```
New-Item -Path '[target]' -ItemType Directory
```
2. Try creating a junction (or symbolic link, substitute with 'SymbolicLink' in the -ItemType parameter)
```
New-Item -Path '[source]' -Value '[target]' -ItemType Junction
```

Expected behavior
-----------------
The junction should be created even if the target path contains square bracket characters

Actual behavior
---------------
 An error message is resulted:
```
new-item : Cannot find path '[target]' because it does not exist.
At line:1 char:1
+ New-Item -Path '[source]' -Value '[target]' -Itemtype Junction
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: (:) [New-Item], PSInvalidOperationException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : InvalidOperation,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.NewItem Command
```
Note: the command **can** be made to work with double escapes, but it seems hacky.
```
new-item -path '[source]' -value "```[target```]" -Itemtype Junction
```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 6.1.7601 S
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

body:
I faced with the performance problem when I tried to recive a long array (e.c. file system entries) from remote pssession. The transfer of such an array takes a long time. Unfortunately it is obvious that Powershell has problems with it.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell

$session = New-PSSession localhost
# or
# $session = New-PSSession -HostName localhost -UserName <username>

$arrayLen = 1024000
Measure-Command{
  Invoke-Command -Session $session -ScriptBlock {
    Write-Host ("Preparing test array {0} elements length..." -f $using:arrayLen)
    $global:result = [Byte[]]::new($using:arrayLen)
    [System.Random]::new().NextBytes($result)
  }
} |% {Write-Host ("Completed in {0} sec`n" -f $_.TotalSeconds)}

Measure-Command{
  Invoke-Command -Session $session -ScriptBlock {
    Write-Host ("Transfer array ({0})" -f $using:arrayLen)
    return $result
  } | Out-Null
} |% {Write-Host ("Completed in {0} sec`n" -f $_.TotalSeconds)}

Measure-Command{
  Invoke-Command -Session $session -ScriptBlock {
    Write-Host ("Transfer same array nested in a single object")
    return @{array = $result}
  } 
} |% {Write-Host ("Completed in {0} sec`n" -f $_.TotalSeconds)}
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
less than a second.
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
Preparing test array 1024000 elements length...
Completed in 0.0211385 sec

Transfer array (1024000)
Completed in 48.0192142 sec

Transfer same array nested in a single object
Completed in 0.0990711 sec
```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17074
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
Previous versions have the same problem

## PR Summary

Fix #4268 
Overlap #5927 (see PowerShell Committee conclusion)

Set default stack size in 10 MB for local pipeline threads.

Each platform uses different default for the thread stack size:
      - Windows 2 MB
      - Linux   8 Mb
      - MacOs   512 KB
 
We should use the same default for all platforms to get predictable behavior.

body:
Looks like we have extremely detailed logging turned on by default.
For example **every** function entry end exit for **every** function invocation.
Can repro on Raspbian 9 and Debian 9.
For example, this command:
`sudo pwsh -c "function foo {};1..100000|%{foo}"`
runs in under 30 seconds, but produces over 300MB in logs in `/var/log/messages` and `/var/log/syslog`
filled with events like this:
```
Feb 22 21:01:58 raspberrypi powershell[26000]: (v6.0.1:A:11) [Command_Lifecycle:CommandStart.Method.Informational] Command foo is Started.#012%n%nContext:%n        Severity = Informational#012        Host Name = ConsoleHost#012        Host Version = 6.0.1#012        Host ID = 9ef94068-9513-42e6-942d-46a28d09ddfb#012        Host Application = /home/pi/PS601/pwsh.dll -c function foo {};1..100000|%{foo}#012        Engine Version = 6.0.1#012        Runspace ID = 2ce73d6a-5384-405f-a77e-c62a0f636008#012        Pipeline ID = 1#012        Command Name = foo#012        Command Type = Function#012        Script Name = #012        Command Path = #012        Sequence Number = 200008#012        User = raspberrypi\root#012        Connected User = #012        Shell ID = Microsoft.PowerShell#012%n%nUser Data:%n%n
Feb 22 21:01:58 raspberrypi powershell[26000]: (v6.0.1:A:11) [Command_Lifecycle:CommandStop.Method.Informational] Command foo is Stopped.#012%n%nContext:%n        Severity = Informational#012        Host Name = ConsoleHost#012        Host Version = 6.0.1#012        Host ID = 9ef94068-9513-42e6-942d-46a28d09ddfb#012        Host Application = /home/pi/PS601/pwsh.dll -c function foo {};1..100000|%{foo}#012        Engine Version = 6.0.1#012        Runspace ID = 2ce73d6a-5384-405f-a77e-c62a0f636008#012        Pipeline ID = 1#012        Command Name = foo#012        Command Type = Function#012        Script Name = #012        Command Path = #012        Sequence Number = 200009#012        User = raspberrypi\root#012        Connected User = #012        Shell ID = Microsoft.PowerShell#012%n%nUser Data:%n%n
```
Such detailed logging runs disk out of space; this probably should Not be a default configuration.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
sudo pwsh -c "function foo {};1..100000|%{foo}"
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

reasonable size of logs

Actual behavior
---------------
over 300 MB generated in logs

Environment data
----------------
Clean installation of PowerShell v6.0.1

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.1
OS                             Linux 4.9.59-v7+ #1047 SMP Sun Oct 29 12:19:23 GMT 2017
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------
Install Powershell Core (latest build) on a machine whose UI Culture is set to something other than en-US... In my case it's en-GB.

Run Update-Help from an administrator command prompt. Then try getting help on a basic command like `help Update-Help -full`. It will tell you that the help files aren't installed.

Expected behavior
-----------------
Help files should be installed.

Actual behavior
---------------
Help files don't get installed.

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.16299
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

I have worked around this by doing Update-Help -UICulture en-US, but I shouldn't have to do this. This command worked fine in Windows PowerShell.

One of the most amazing things about PowerShell is the rich help system. But if it doesn't work for a huge amount of users (anyone not in the US) then what's the point?

See this related issue: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/5534

body:
The Dockerfiles for the ubuntu images do not follow the [best practices](https://docs.docker.com/develop/develop-images/dockerfile_best-practices/#run).  They do not remove the apt cache thus causing docker images to be larger than necessary.

An illustration of this is the following instruction. https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docker/release/ubuntu16.04/Dockerfile#L47
```
RUN apt-get update \
    && apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends \
	powershell
```

It should include 
```
&& rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*
```
which is done in the previous apt-get instruction at https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docker/release/ubuntu16.04/Dockerfile#L26

Cleaning up the apt cache in the ubuntu 14.04 image will reduce the image size by 21MB (5%).

labels.description: specific to affecting the build
labels.name: Area-Maintainers-Build

title: Ubuntu based Docker images have unnecessary apt cache bloat

body: The readme for the [Powershell Docker Hub Repo](https://hub.docker.com/r/microsoft/powershell/) does not follow the typical format of a Docker Hub readme and is therefore not very useful in the context of Docker.  I would say one of the most important aspects is missing.  The readme should include a list of what the active tags are and provide links to the Dockerfiles they were generated from.  The readme should be explaining how to use the Docker images.  Using the GitHub readme is not appropriate in this context.  See https://hub.docker.com/r/microsoft/dotnet/ as a reference for the type of content that is expected.

body:
It'd be nice if we could use SSH PSRemote sessions with our configured session `ssh-agent`-compatible daemon to get the required security information/

For instance, I use `gpg-agent` to store my SSH private key securely on my Yubikey 4, as a result my key doesn't actually exist on my laptop.

From looking at the output of `ps` while `New-PSSession` is run, it appears you guys are shelling out to `ssh` anyway, and the `ssh` client supports the ssh-agent by default, so I assume something is being done to disable it for the invocation.

body:
# Exception Handling in PowerShell is the pits (part 1)
### I am _re-filing_ this from Connect from as it appears to have gone missing again.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
try{
get-contentnosuchfile-ErrorActionStop
}catch[System.Management.Automation.ActionPreferenceStopException]{
$_.PSTypeNames,$_.Exception.PSTypeNames,$_.Exception.InnerException.PSTypeNames
} 
```

Output:
```
System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord
System.Object
System.Management.Automation.ItemNotFoundException
System.Management.Automation.SessionStateException
System.Management.Automation.RuntimeException
System.SystemException
System.Exception
System.Object
```


Expected behavior
-----------------

Since I "caught" an ActionPreferenceStopException, I should be able to see the ActionPreferenceStopException.

Actual behavior
---------------

PowerShell unwrapped the exception and gave me only what *caused* the exception. If I wanted that, I *would have* said so, since this works (and produces the same output as above)

```powershell
try {
   get-content nosuchfile -ErrorAction Stop
} catch [System.Management.Automation.ItemNotFoundException] {
   Write-Host "It's an ItemNotFoundException, obviously"
   $_.PSTypeNames, $_.Exception.PSTypeNames, $_.Exception.InnerException.PSTypeNames
} 
```

## NOTE: THE REAL PROBLEM

It is *not* possible to catch the specific type explicitly, and **also** handle the generic case:

```powershell
try {
   get-content nosuchfile -ErrorAction Stop
} catch [System.Management.Automation.ItemNotFoundException] {
   Write-Host "It's an ItemNotFoundException, which I can fix ... "
}  catch [System.Management.Automation.ActionPreferenceStopException] {
   $_.PSTypeNames, $_.Exception.PSTypeNames, $_.Exception.InnerException.PSTypeNames
} 
```

Environment data
----------------

This has *always* been a problem, and it persists in PowerShell 6.

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.15063
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3

WSManStackVersion              3.0

```

I opened https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/6050 with the goal of figuring out how to use SQLite with PowerShell 6. With that issue, I learned how to install packages, but I did not figure out how to import and use them. It was suggested that I open an issue with the SQLite package owners and I did that with https://github.com/aspnet/Microsoft.Data.Sqlite/issues/485. I have learned a lot with that issue, but am still struggling to achieve my original goal of using SQLite with PowerShell 6.

Steps to reproduce
----------------
```powershell
# Install the packages
Install-Package Microsoft.Data.Sqlite -Scope CurrentUser -Verbose
Install-Package Microsoft.Data.Sqlite.Core -Scope CurrentUser -Verbose

# Import the packages
$Root = "C:\Users\egagn\AppData\Local\PackageManagement\NuGet\Packages"
[void][Reflection.Assembly]::LoadFile("$Root\Microsoft.Data.Sqlite.Core.2.0.0\lib\netstandard2.0\Microsoft.Data.Sqlite.dll")
[void][Reflection.Assembly]::LoadFile("$Root\SQLitePCLRaw.core.1.1.9\lib\netstandard1.1\SQLitePCLRaw.core.dll")

# Try to use the packages
$Connection = New-Object -TypeName Microsoft.Data.Sqlite.SqliteConnection
$Connection.ConnectionString = "Data Source=C:\vault.db"
```

This results in the following error

body:
I'm writing a function where I want to output paths, but I want to provide a `Relative` switch to give the user the option to see the relative path of the file instead of the full path (because paths are long, and there's a lot of other data).

I need to use `Convert-Path` to produce "normal" looking file system paths, but I want them to be relative.  

### I can't use Resolve-Path because:

a) It changes it's output *Type* based on the `-Relative` switch (this is just silly, but it breaks everything because ...)
b) When it's not -Relative, it changes it's output based on the input:

```posh
I  PS> Resolve-Path C:\Windows | % ToString
C:\Windows

I  PS> Resolve-Path FileSystem::C:\Windows | % ToString
FileSystem::C:\Windows

I  PS> Resolve-Path Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\FileSystem::C:\Windows | % ToString
Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\FileSystem::C:\Windows

I  PS> Resolve-Path Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\FILESYSTEM::\WINDOWS | % ToString
Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\FILESYSTEM::\WINDOWS
```

So, I want the paths relative to the common source root (e.g. for the Coverage report in Pester). 

To get a relative path, I need to use `Resolve-Path` instead of `Convert-Path` and if I'm *not* using the relative path, I need to use Convert-Path to avoid having the long FileSystem provider name in the output?

I am currently doing this:

```posh
        ${function:Resolve} = if($Relative) {
            { process { $_ | Resolve-Path -Relative } }
        } else {
            { process { $_ | Convert-Path } }
        }
```

body:
From `docs/installation/linux.md`:

>Note: When installing PowerShell Core, OpenSUSE may report that nothing provides `libcurl`. `libcurl` should already be installed on supported versions of OpenSUSE. Run `zypper search libcurl` to confirm. The error will present 2 'solutions'. Choose 'Solution 2' to continue installing PowerShell Core.

1. If the intention is that the user should choose the `break powershell-6.0.1-1.rhel.7.x86_64 by ignoring some of its dependencies` option, then describing the option text explicitly ("Choose the solution to ignore dependencies and install the package anyway.") would be better. I don't believe zypper has to deterministically give that one as "Solution 2" and it's a vague instruction anyway.

1. It would be better to tell users to run `zypper search --provides --match-exact '/usr/lib64/libcurl.so.4'` instead of just `zypper search libcurl` to verify that they have the required library. The current command finds all packages that have `libcurl` in the name. While it's obvious which package the user should be looking for, there's no reason to be vague about it.

1. I assume this situation happens because you reuse the RHEL package for openSUSE and RHEL's libcurl package provides "libcurl". Why not make a separate package for openSUSE that requires "libcurl4" so that this workaround is not needed in the first place?

body:
In order to get help for a parameter only the _original_ name is recognized by `Get-Help -Parameter`.

It should be possible to ask for parameter help by alias names too, similar to how `Get-Command -ParameterName ad` is able to locate `Get-ChildItem` via (any of) the `Directory` parameter's alias names, such as `ad`.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
# Ask for help by original parameter name.
Get-Help -Parameter Directory Get-ChildItem

# Ask for help by parameter *alias*.
Get-Help -Parameter ad Get-ChildItem
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

Both commands should output details about the specified parameter, irrespective of whether the original name or an alias was used.

Actual behavior
---------------

```none

-Directory
    
    Required?                    false
    Position?                    Named
    Accept pipeline input?       false
    Parameter set name           (All)
    Aliases                      ad, d
    Dynamic?                     true
    

Get-Help : No parameter matches criteria ad.
At line:1 char:1
+ Get-Help -Parameter ad Get-ChildItem
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : InvalidArgument: (System.Manageme...CommandHelpInfo:ProviderCommandHelpInfo) [Get-Help], PSArgumentException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : NoParmsFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetHelpCommand
 ```

That is, asking for `-Directory` via an _alias name_ failed.

body:
be700729d689f7998110a38889b7962e890e387d changed `FileSystemProvider`'s `Encoding` parameter to use `ArgumentToEncodingTransformationAttribute`. However this attibute is marked `internal` so third-party content cmdlet providers cannot use it.

Please make this attribute public, or provide some way for third-party content cmdlet providers to have an `-Encoding` parameter with the same functionality as the built-in `FileSystemProvider`.

Edit: The `EncodingConversion` class and its constants too.

This is an extremely weird one...

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
Giraff
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
Giraffe
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
Giraff
```

This only happens when the last letter of the remaining string has an "e". If I'd change the initial string to "DogTestsPaketApp" then it would work as expected:

```powershell
> "DogTestsPaketApp".Trim("App").Trim("Paket").Trim("Tests")
Dog
```

Environment data


body:
The scripts named in `ScriptsToProcess` are processed only for the first module that is imported.  This has the following implications for SessionStates that need to include the alterations caused by `ScriptsToProcess`:

* An `Import-Module` statement that usually causes changes to the active SessionState does not make those changes if the module named in the statement happens to already be loaded.
* Where more than one SessionState imports the same module, at most one of those SessionStates will have the alterations caused by `ScriptsToProcess`.  Which one depends on the order the module importing occurs.

A workaround for this might be to use `Import-Module -Force`.  However, if the module also involves PowerShell classes, then it might run afoul of PowerShell/PowerShell#2505.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

#### ScriptsToProcess.psd1

```powershell
@{
    ModuleVersion = '0.1.0'
    RootModule = 'ScriptsToProcessTest.psm1'
    ScriptsToProcess = 'ScriptsToProcessTest.ps1'
}
```

#### ScriptsToProcess.psm1

empty file

#### ScriptsToProcess.ps1

```powershell
Write-Host 'ScriptsToProcessTest.ps1'
$v = 'importerscope.v'
```

#### Invoke the following

```powershell
Remove-Variable v -ea si
Remove-Module ScriptsToProcessTest -ea si

New-Module m {
    Write-Host 'module'
    Import-Module ScriptsToProcessTest
    function Get-V {$v}
} | Import-Module

Write-Host 'global'
Import-Module ScriptsToProcessTest
"v: $v"
"Get-V: $(Get-V)"
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
module
ScriptsToProcessTest.ps1
global
ScriptsToProcessTest.ps1
v: importerscope.v
Get-V: importerscope.v
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
module
ScriptsToProcessTest.ps1
global
v:
Get-V: importerscope.v
```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value                                            
----                           -----                                            
PSVersion                      6.0.0                                            
PSEdition                      Core                                             
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0                                           
OS                             Microsoft Windows 6.3.9600                       
Platform                       Win32NT                                          
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}                          
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3                                              
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1                                          
WSManStackVersion              3.0                                              
```

I'm having some issues calling a WCF service from Linux. 
The same code works fine on Windows. 

I'm getting this error when trying to use basic authentication:

`The HTTP request is unauthorized with client authentication scheme 'Basic'. The authentication header received from the server was 'Basic realm="local.realm"'.
`

The service is hosted in IIS on a Windows machine.
Unfortunately, I cannot share the web service or the code behind it.

The client was generated as a "Connected Service" in Visual Studio 2017.
The source code for the module is available on GitHub:
https://github.com/pkjaer/tridion-powershell-modules/tree/pwsh-core-support/Tridion.Community.PowerShell

Specifically, the generated client is here:
https://github.com/pkjaer/tridion-powershell-modules/blob/pwsh-core-support/Tridion.Community.PowerShell/Tridion.Community.PowerShell/Connected%20Services/CoreService/Reference.cs

And the class that sets up the bindings and such is here:
https://github.com/pkjaer/tridion-powershell-modules/blob/pwsh-core-support/Tridion.Community.PowerShell/Tridion.Community.PowerShell/Client.cs

None of the bindings work on Linux currently, but I figured the `BasicHttpBinding` would be the easiest to get running first.

Since it works in PowerShell 6 on a Windows machine, but not on Linux, I'm thinking there is something in the OS that behaves differently. 



Expected behavior
-----------------

The client is able to communicate with the WCF service using Basic authentication and a BasicHttpBinding.


Actual behavior
---------------
Any call to the service gives the following error:

```
The HTTP request is unauthorized with client authentication scheme 'Basic'. 
The authentication header received from the server was 'Basic realm="local.realm"'.

```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
Name                           Value                                           
----                           -----                                           
PSVersion                      6.0.1                                           
PSEdition                      Core                                            
GitCommitId                    v6.0.1                                          
OS                             Linux 3.10.0-693.11.6.el7.x86_64 #1 SMP Thu D...
```

(Above is for RHEL but I've tried Ubuntu (16 & 17) as well, with the same result)

body:
**Wishful thinking**:

```powershell
# Script block as replacement operand allows dynamic substitutions.
# TBD: how to refer to the match at hand in the script block.
> 'Increment these numbers: 1 2 3' -replace '\d+', { [int] $Args.Value + 1 }   
Increment these numbers: 2 3 4
```

Sometimes string replacements need to be _dynamic_, i.e., the replacement string must be _derived from the match at hand_.

Consider the following (contrived example):

You want to increment all numbers in an input string; e.g.:  

`'Increment these numbers: 1 2 3'` -> `'Increment these numbers: 2 3 4'`

Currently, `-replace` doesn't support this type of replacement, because the replacement operand can only _statically_ refer to the match at hand (`$&` for the match in full, `$1` for the 1st capture group's match (if any), ...).

Thus, to achieve this kind of substitution the .NET Framework must currently be used:

```powershell
> [regex]::Replace('Increment these numbers: 1 2 3', '\d+', { param($match) [int] $match.Value + 1 })
Increment these numbers: 2 3 4
```

Needless to say, this is neither PowerShell-like nor simple.

---

Supporting the syntax as proposed at the top would greatly simplify such operations.

### Syntax details

The simplest approach is to use `[regex]::Replace()` as-is behind the scenes, and let  the script block reference the match at hand - which is passed as a `[System.Text.RegularExpressions.Match]` instance - via `$Args` (or, optionally, an explicitly defined parameter via `param()`).

The alternative is to stick with the `$&`, `$1`, ... syntax, but that would require behind-the-scenes manipulation of the script block.

### Backward-compatibility considerations

Currently, attempting to use a script block as the replacement operand simply _stringifies_ that block (i.e., uses its _string contents_ as the replacement string).

Since this behavior isn't useful, it's hard to imagine anyone relying on it, so this change probably falls into [Bucket 3: Unlikely Grey Area](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/dev-process/breaking-change-contract.md#bucket-3-unlikely-grey-area)


Environment data
----------------

Written as of  PowerShell Core v6.0.1

body:
In the context of _implicit_ stringification as part of _expandable strings_, `[System.Management.Automation.PSCustomObject]` instances expand to a hashtable-_like_ representation.

By contrast, calling `.ToString()` _explicitly_ yields the _empty string_; only `.psobject.ToString()` results in the same representation as when string-expanding.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
$co = [pscustomobject] @{ one = 'for the road' }
"string-expanded: [$co]"
".psobject.ToString: [{0}]" -f $co.psobject.ToString()
".ToString: [{0}]" -f $co.ToString()
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
string-expanded: [@{one=for the road}]
.psobject.ToString: [@{one=for the road}]
.ToString: [@{one=for the road}]
```

All three approaches should result in the same stringification.

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
string-expanded: [@{one=for the road}]
.psobject.ToString: [@{one=for the road}]
.ToString: []
```

Note how `$co.ToString()` returned the empty string.

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.1
Windows PowerShell v5.1
```

body:
[Closed, because it is based on a misconception of how `-ExpandProperty` works.]

`-ExpandProperty` makes `Select-Object` return a single property _value_, which is mutually exclusive with `-Property`, which outputs a _custom object_ with the specified properties.

Currently, `-Property` is quietly ignored when `-ExpandProperty` is also specified.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
[pscustomobject] @{ one = 1; two = 2; three = 3 } | 
  Select-Object -ExpandProperty one -Property three
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

A statement-terminating error complaining about mutually exclusive parameters should be issued.

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
1
```

That is, the `-Property` argument was silently _ignored_.

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.1
Windows PowerShell v5.1
```

body:
I often use Restart-Computer to restart two or more computers along with the Wait parameter so I know when they are back online.  Sometimes I will get one or more computer fail to respond after the reboot.  Unfortunately the progress bar just show a count of the number of computers that are complete.  It then hangs waiting for the non-responding computers to respond without giving any indication as to which one that is.

Restart-Service has a nice warning message that it's waiting for a service to stop/start.  This would be ideal here but that could be quite spammy if it was doing that for every computer being restarted.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
Restart-Computer -ComputerName COMPUTER01, COMPUTER02 -Wait -Verbose
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
Give some indication as to which computer it is waiting for
```

Actual behavior
---------------

![Restart-Computer](https://i.imgur.com/fWmXrYZ.png)

title: Invoke-WebRequest is ignoring -MaximumRedirection 0

body:
HttpClient and HttpClientHandler, while implementing IDisposable, are intended to be reused. not re using HttpClient results in significant overhead and loses out on the ability to reuse TCP pools. We currently create and dispose HttpClient and HttpClientHandler instances on every call to the web cmdlets. With large numbers of HTTP requests this can get expensive.

We should investigate the introduction of a single HttpClient/HttpClientHandler. One of my specific concerns is that it may not play nicely in multi-threading scenarios. a `static` instance of these is supposed ot be thread safe, but, I have no clue if a change in one thread to HttpClientHandler.Credentials (for example) will have an impact on the handler in another thread. *shrugs

Steps to reproduce
------------------
I've experienced this with the Import-Module cmdlet, but it may be present in other cmdlets too. I've used the PowerShellGet module in my examples but it happens with every other module I've tried. The Import-Module cmdlet has a parameter MinimumVersion with the alias Version and the common parameter Verbose.

In the default PowerShell 6 console I type:
```powershell
Import-Module PowerShellGet -ve
```
I then type [TAB] which results in:
```powershell
Import-Module PowerShellGet -Version
```

Expected behavior
-----------------
 I expect that when I use tab completion with -v, -ve, or -ver, that the suggestions will cycle between -Version and -Verbose. After the second [TAB] key press I expect to see:
```powershell
Import-Module PowerShellGet -Verbose
```

Actual behavior
---------------
After the second [TAB] key press I actually see:
```powershell
Import-Module PowerShellGet -Version
```

If I type -ver and then [TAB], the behavior is the same; I only see -Version. If I type -v and then [TAB], the behavior is as expected, the suggestions cycle between -Version and -Verbose.

body:
From the quibbles department:

According to [Approved Verbs for PowerShell Commands](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/developer/cmdlet/approved-verbs-for-windows-powershell-commands), the official alias prefix for `Select-*` cmdlets is `sc`, not `sl` (the latter is for `Split-*` cmdlets).

Therefore, the naming-convention-compliant alias for `Select-String` should be `scs`, not `sls`.

It's probably too late to remove `sls`, but we could add `scs`.

Either way, a note in the documentation would be helpful.

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.0
```

body:
I have been experimenting with a (hopefully) more robust mechanism for mocking commands than Pester currently uses.  [Here is a proof of concept](https://gist.github.com/alx9r/ed9d837b83866ddae4b079700e935e66).  In general, the mechanism relies on invoking scriptblocks with the SessionState where the mock needs to exist.  This is trivial for a SessionState associated with a module: Invoking `& $module $scriptblock` achieves the desired result.  I haven't, however, found a straightforward way of invoking a scriptblock defined inside a module with the "global" SessionState.

Consider this working code

```PowerShell
Get-Module LibraryModule,m | Remove-Module
New-Module LibraryModule {
    $sb = {
        Write-Host 'control flow: 1'
        Write-Host $v
        'output'
        Write-Host 'control flow: 3'
    }
    function DownStream {
        param([Parameter(ValueFromPipeline)]$i)
        process {
            Write-Host 'control flow: 2'
        }
    }
    function InvokeWithModuleSessionState {
        param([psmoduleinfo]$mi)
        & $mi $sb | DownStream
    }
    function InvokeWithGlobalSessionState {
        [CmdletBinding()]
        param($ss)

        <#
        This doesn't execute in the "global" SessionState.  
        (ie. it has no access to 'g.v')
        #>
        # & $ss.InvokeCommand.NewScriptBlock($sb) | DownStream

        <#
        Each of these neither
            1. has the correct control flow (ie. they don't yield to DownStream), nor
            2. executes in the global SessionState (ie. they have no access to 'g.v').
        #>

        # $ss.InvokeCommand.InvokeScript($sb) | DownStream
        # $ss.InvokeCommand.InvokeScript($ss,$sb,$null) | DownStream
        # $ss.InvokeCommand.InvokeScript($true,$sb,$null,$null) | DownStream
        # $ss.InvokeCommand.InvokeScript($false,$sb,$null,$null) | DownStream
        # $ss.InvokeCommand.InvokeScript($sb,$true,'Output',$null,$null) | DownStream
        # $ss.InvokeCommand.InvokeScript($sb,$false,'Output',$null,$null) | DownStream

        <#
        This works, but it's in bucket 4.
        #>

        $copyOfSb = [scriptblock]::Create($sb)
        $flags = [System.Reflection.BindingFlags]'Instance,NonPublic'
        $internalSessionState = [System.Management.Automation.SessionState].GetProperty('Internal', $flags).GetValue($ss, $null)
        $property = [ScriptBlock].GetProperty('SessionStateInternal', $flags)
        $property.SetValue($copyOfSb, $internalSessionState, $null) | Out-Null
        & $copyOfSb | DownStream
    }
} | Import-Module

New-Module m {
    $v = 'm.v'
} | Import-Module

& {
    $v = 'g.v'
    Write-Host '=== Module ==='
    InvokeWithModuleSessionState -sb $sb -mi (Get-Module m)

    Write-Host '=== Global ==='
    InvokeWithGlobalSessionState -ss $ExecutionContext.SessionState
}
```

which outputs

```none
=== Module ===
control flow: 1
m.v
control flow: 2
control flow: 3
=== Global ===
control flow: 1
g.v
control flow: 2
control flow: 3
```

This implementation of `InvokeWithGlobalSessionState` relies on private reflection to bind a scriptblock to the SessionState.  This is clearly vulnerable to bucket 4 changes which, per the [breaking changes contract](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/dev-process/breaking-change-contract.md), "don't require up-front approval."  I'd like to avoid such sudden breakage, if there is a better way.

1. Is there a supported way of binding an unbound scriptblock to the "global" session state?
2. Is there a supported way of invoking an unbound scriptblock in the "global" session state?  In other words, is there a supported analog to `& $module $scriptblock` that works for the "global" session state as opposed to a module session state?
3. Is there some other way of creating a scriptblock from a module, but invoking it in the "global" session state?

title: Is there a supported way of binding an unbound scriptblock to the "global" SessionState?

body:
Per RFC 8288, relation types on `Link` response headers MUST be compared in a case-insensitive fashion. HTTP servers SHOULD send relation types as all lower case, but parsing them MUST be case-insensitive. 

Currently, the `RelationLink` dictionary we create is case sensitive. This should be change to case-insensitive, An HTTP server sending more than one of the same relation type (case-insensitive) is not RFC compliant, therefore a case-insensitive dictionary should not encounter keys of the same characters with different casing.

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/0ad9fc9d7057bbe50c77b7d297f102a68380918b/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Utility/commands/utility/WebCmdlet/Common/WebRequestPSCmdlet.Common.cs#L1593


Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
$uri = 'https://api.github.com/repositories/49609581/issues?page=2'
$response = Invoke-WebRequest -Uri $Uri
$response.RelationLink.next -eq 'https://api.github.com/repositories/49609581/issues?page=3'
$response.RelationLink.Next -eq 'https://api.github.com/repositories/49609581/issues?page=3'
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
True
True
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
True
False
```

Environment data
----------------

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.16299
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

```

labels.description: The issue is fixed.

## PR Summary

If `$env:PAGER` is a command with args, it doesn't work correctly as the current code tries to find a command matching `$env:PAGER` which fails due to the args.  Fix is to split `$env:PAGER` into the command and the args, find the first occurrence of the command and pass back the args.

No tests as this is interactive only.  Manually validated with `less -w` which highlights the first lien of a new page.

body:
`build.psm1` was recently updated to use '`Save-Module`' in `Restore-PSPester `#6112 
Side effects of this update broke Docker package validation tests.
Specifically:
1) Now `Restore-PSPester` requires` -Destination `directory to exist and throws error if it doesn't; Previously `Restore-PSPester` was creating it.
![restorepester0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11860095/36054648-7e13407e-0def-11e8-994a-677fe6e1d61c.png)

2) Default `-Destination` directory is NOT based on `PSModulePath`, but rather on a `(Get-PSOptions -DefaultToNew).Output`, which is not helpful at all since it requires to provide full path to the module in case pwsh is run from an installed package as opposed to built from clone repo.
![restorepester1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11860095/36054653-81c861b8-0def-11e8-8dc5-576fd0a97bc7.png)

body:
## PR Summary

Fix #5515
Fix #4814
Fix #5158 

Close #5725 

- Can compile a source from parameters (TypeDefinition and MemberDefinition).
- Can compile from files.
- Can compile only to a file (without assembly loading).
- Don't recompile and don't reload if the sources have not changed.
- Implemented `-IgnoreWarnings` - ignore warnings as errors. By default the cmdlet consider warnings as errors.
- Added VisualBasic support.
- Added new `-CompilerOptions` parameter allow set Roslyn command line parameters including:
    - Parser options.
    - Compile options.
    - Emit options.

**ATTENTION:** The `CompilerOptions` can be specified along with other options like `-OutputAssembly`, `-Language` and `-IgnoreWarnings`. The explicit setting parameters will take precedence over the same settings specified in `-CompileOptions`.

See docs about the compiler options:
https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/blob/master/docs/compilers/CSharp/CommandLine.md
https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/blob/master/docs/compilers/Visual%20Basic/CommandLine.md

**ATTENTION:** `-OutputType` default is `Library`. If `-OutputType` is absent the `-OutputType` default overlaps a value in `CompileOptions`. In other words output type ("target" ot "t" in command line) is always ignored in `CompileOptions`. We have to use `-OutputType` to set an output type.

@TravisEz13 @PaulHigin Please audit security of the `-ExtendedOptions` parameter.

body:
Scriptblocks seem to be PowerShell's analog to other languages' anonymous functions.  I'm finding scriptblock's role as anonymous anonymous functions critical to writing maintainable code.  Unlike anonymous functions in C#, for example, how a scriptblock is invoked seems to affect its behavior.  The method of invocation seems affect behavior in (at least) the following ways:

1. Whether variable assignments in the scriptblock have side-effects in the definition's scope.  
2. Whether `param()` can be used.

Consider the following code:

```PowerShell
New-Module m {
    $v = 'c'
    function f {
        param($sb)
        % $sb
    }
    function g {
        param($sb)
        & $sb -p1 'p1 is bound'
    }
} | Out-Null

'--- & ---'
& {
    $v = 'v is not modified by g'
    g -sb {
        param( $p1 )
        process
        {
            $p1
            $v = 'modified by g'
        }
    }
    $v
}

'--- % ---'
& {
    $v = 'v is not modified by f'
    f -sb {
        param( $p1 )  # <== these line are unused because % does not 
        $p1           # <== use parameter binding on this scriptblock
        $v = 'v is modified by f'
    }
    $v
}
```

which outputs 

```none
--- & ---
p1 is bound
v is not modified by g
--- % ---
v is modified by f
```

This seems to demonstrate the following:

* assignments in scriptblocks invoked using `&` **do not** have side effects in the definition's scope
* assignments in scriptblocks invoked using `%` **do** have side effects in the definition's scope
* `&` supports `param()`

Judging from [its help topic](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/foreach-object?view=powershell-6), `%` does not support using `param()`.

The following table summarizes the behavior of `%` and `&` in these respects:

| Invocation Method | supports using `param()` | variable assignment has side-effects |
|-------------------|--------------------------|--------------------------------------|
| %                 | no                       | yes                                  |
| &                 | yes                      | no                                   |

Is there a way to invoke scriptblocks that supports using both `param()` and variable assignments with side effects?

labels.name: Issue-Question

title: Is there a way to invoke a scriptblock in its definition's scope and use `param()`?

body:
Comparing two large arrays (~75K entries) with Compare-Object lists items common to both objects.  Comparing the two arrays by iterating through each element identifies entries that are different (which is what I'd expect Compare-Object to do).

Note: this is borne out of the need to determine whether file repositories are in sync over globally distributed NAS devices.

Below, generate two arrays with the same content, with random differences scattered between both.

Difference between Compare-Object and CompareArrays.ps1 (note: this script will take a long time to run, hence the need to use Compare-Object as this is _quick_!)

Steps to reproduce
------------------
Script: genArrays.ps1

```powershell
#!/usr/bin/pwsh
#requires -Version 6
$Random = [System.Random]::New()

$RandomStrings = @(
    ([string]::Join("", (0..25| ForEach-Object {$Random.Next(9)})))
    ([string]::Join("", (0..25| ForEach-Object {$Random.Next(9)})))
    ([string]::Join("", (0..25| ForEach-Object {$Random.Next(9)})))
)

$PathLength = 9
$Records = 75000
$RootPath = "/root/instance/filestore100"
$Hostnames = "host1.domain.local", "host2.domain.remote"
$Files = @(@(),@())
$FileCount = @(0, 0)
$FileRecord = @(@{}, @{})

0..$Records|Foreach-Object {
    $Record = $_
    if ($Record % 1000 -eq 0) {
        Write-Warning "$($Record)"
    }
    $Offset = $Random.Next(7)
    $Filename = "$($RootPath)/$($RandomStrings[0].SubString($Offset,$PathLength))/$($RandomStrings[1].SubString($Offset,$PathLength))/$($RandomStrings[2].SubString($Offset,$PathLength))/$([guid]::NewGuid().Guid)"
    $Size = $Random.Next(128*1mb)
    if (($Random.Next() % 23) -eq 0) {
        $AddSize = $Random.Next(1mb)
    } elseif (($Random.Next() % 29) -eq 0) {
        $AddSize = 0 - $Random.Next(1mb)
    } else {
        $AddSize = 0
    }
    if (($Random.Next() % 107) -ne 0) {
        $Files[0] += @{
            Host = $Hostnames[0]
            Size = ($Size + $AddSize)
            Filename = $Filename
        }
    }
    if (($Random.Next() % 103) -ne 0) {
        $Files[1] += @{
            Host = $Hostnames[1]
            Size = $Size
            Filename = $Filename
        }
    }
}
$FileCount[0] = $Files[0].Size|Measure-Object -Sum
$FileCount[1] = $Files[1].Size|Measure-Object -Sum

$FileRecord[0] = @{
    Used = $FileCount[0].Sum
    Host = $Hostnames[0]
    Filecount = $FileCount[0].Count
    Files = $Files[0]
    StorageType = "Primary"
}

$FileRecord[1] = @{
    Used = $FileCount[1].Sum
    Host = $Hostnames[1]
    Filecount = $FileCount[1].Count
    Files = $Files[1]
    StorageType = "Secondary"
}
@{
    Instance = "Instance"
    Filestore = 100
    Report = @($FileRecord[0],$FileRecord[1])
    Root = "/root/instance"
}

```

Script: CompareArrays.ps1
```powershell
#!/usr/bin/pwsh
$Count = 0
$FakeReport.Report[0].Files|Foreach-Object {
        $Count++
        if (($Count % 100) -eq 0) {
                Write-Warning "$Count"
        }
        $FileObject = $_

        $OrigIndex = $FakeReport.Report[0].Files.Filename.IndexOf($FileObject.Filename)
        #$OrigIndex
        $NewIndex = $FakeReport.Report[1].Files.Filename.IndexOf($FileObject.Filename)
        #$NewIndex
        if ($NewIndex -lt 0) {
                $FakeReport.Report[0].Files[$OrigIndex]
        }

}
$Count = 0
$FakeReport.Report[1].Files|Foreach-Object {
        $Count++
        if (($Count % 100) -eq 0) {
                Write-Warning "$Count"
        }
        $FileObject = $_

        $OrigIndex = $FakeReport.Report[1].Files.Filename.IndexOf($FileObject.Filename)
        $NewIndex = $FakeReport.Report[0].Files.Filename.IndexOf($FileObject.Filename)
        if ($NewIndex -lt 0) {
                $FakeReport.Report[1].Files[$OrigIndex]
        }
}

```

Generate data:
```powershell
$FakeReport = ./genArrays.ps1
```
Compare data:
```powershell
$Result1 = Compare-Object $FakeReport.Report[0].Files $FakeReport.Report[1].Files -PassThru

$Result2 = ./CompareArrays.ps1
```


Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
$Result1 should have similar content to $Result2.  Entries in $Result1 should not exist in $FakeReport.Report[0].Files _and_ $FakeReport.Report[1].Files

$Result2 contains entries that either do not exist in $FakeReport.Report[0].Files or do not exist in $FakeReport.Report[1].Files, which is what I would _expect_ to see in $Result1.

```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
$Result1 contains items common to both $FakeReport.Report[0].Files and $FakeReport.Report[1].Files
```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.1
OS                             Linux 4.13.0-32-generic #35~16.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Thu Jan 25 10:13:43 UTC 2018
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

```
